awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research in Symmetries at the University of Kentucky
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site at the University of Kentucky. Eight undergraduate students per year will participate in the 10-week summer REU site in Physics and Astronomy. REU students will participate in research projects that address issues at the forefront of modern physics and astronomy: What is the origin of matter in the universe? Is there new high-energy physics which modifies the magnetic moment of the muon? What is the nature of dark matter and dark energy that dominate the composition of the universe? What prevents stars from forming from the cold dense gas in the centers of massive clusters of galaxies? What types of phase transitions must be understood in terms of topological invariants instead of broken symmetries? What materials host exotic quantum spin liquid phases? REU students will be trained with knowledge and skills to address these fundamental questions. 

The REU program focuses around individual mentored research projects in nuclear physics, condensed matter physics, and astronomy, loosely related through the central theme of symmetry. These research topics are part of the research programs of faculty mentors funded by NSF, the Department of Energy, and NASA, tailored for accessibility to 2nd and 3rd year undergraduates. They involve advanced physics techniques that are not normally available at smaller institutions. REU participants will work together with graduate students and postdocs in the lab, interacting daily with their mentors to produce publishable results in these areas at the frontiers of physics and astronomy. The program will also include professional development through a series of seminars and workshops and include specific technical training in computation and data analysis. Students will present results at a local poster session and be encouraged to present at national conferences. This project is jointly funded by the Division of Physics and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project established a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at in Physics and Astronomy at the University of Kentucky. The goals of this program were to:  1) Enhance interest in physics, astronomy, and technology of undergraduate participants from RK/CA (Rural Kentucky/Central Appalachia) where there are limited research opportunities;  2) Train participants with skills relevant to graduate research in contemporary fields of physics and enhance the STEM workforce in RK/CA; and  3) Strengthen research ties between UK and minority/undergraduate post-secondary institutions in RK/CA to provide technical expertise and research and educational opportunities.

Intellectual Merit:  Over the course of ten weeks each year during the summers of 2021--2023, individual undergraduate students were paired with a mentor where they worked on a physics/astronomy related research project.  In total, 23 undergraduate participants were funded through this NSF project, and an additional 33 students participated in the same program through other sources of funding.  The program included training in methods of scientific research, specialized skills and concepts workshops, professional development, and an extensive social program to help the participants identify themselves as scientists and explore their interest in physics and astronomy.  Each participant presented their research with a short talk, a poster, and a technical report.  Many of the participants further presented their research at local, regional, and national conferences.

The program was assessed using a convergent parallel mixed-methods approach to allow for both quantitative and qualitative data to be collected at the same time.  Questions investigated were: (1) How well did the REU project enhance student interest in physics? (2) How well did participants become trained with relevant research skills? (3) How successful was the REU program according to mentors and fellows? (4) Are gender differences present in perceptions of students' evaluation of their research experiences in the Physics REU program? If so, what are they?  Pre/post semi-structured interviews were also conducted with the REU fellows, and post-interviews were conducted with research mentors.

Broader Impact: The three goals of the program focused on enhancing the scientific interest, workforce, and technical expertise in RK/CA. 15 of the 23 NSF participants and 29 of the 33 other participants were from this area or enrolled in a college in Kentucky.  Four of these students enrolled in the graduate program in Physics and Astronomy at the University of Kentucky after participating in the REU program.

The NSF-funded students recruited for all three years included more women and underrepresented minorities than those that have received a bachelor’s degree in physics. Based on the surveys and in some of the interviews, all students felt that their research skills improved as well as their physics conceptual understanding. The last two years had several students comment on how they are better able to relate to their physics curriculums now that they have engaged in physics research.  Others reported that they have a better understanding of where they would really like to work and do, for example, one student stated, "I would really love to work in a national observatory... [this program] actually even proving my point to myself that I really love astronomy."  There were significantly higher responses from females in survey responses about how the internship was going to help them in their research efforts.  Since these female participants have reported increased confidence and technical skills, it seems logical that this would translate to self-perceived improvement in research skills overall and it would improve their own evaluation of their future potential as a STEM scientist.
